direction.raw_text: Aug 15th 1997 rewrite by Jon Cohen
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And then, slowly emerging from the mists of darkness, a pale, beautifully proportioned FACE. The oval face is female, a woman of indeterminate age, her features as fragile as porcelain.  Her eyes are closed in sleep, or in death ... or in something in between. Now TWO MORE FACES emerge out of the darkness.  They are male, and they float into position on either side of the female.  They are just as ethereally beautiful, just as pale, and like the female their eyes are closed. The ghostly lips of the female begin to twitch.  Her features, which have been expressionless, suddenly contort, mask-like, into the face of a woman in fear.  Her eyes open. The male face on her right contorts too.  His features warp into an angry snarl -- the mask of a man enraged.  His eyes open. The male face on her left takes on the expression of a young boy, a boy who is terribly frightened.  His eyes open wide. As if they are lost in the same terrible waking dream, a sudden and unnerving exchange begins ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All we see are three faces on the screen mouthing words but we can imagine a terrible struggle taking place before us: a man with scissors lunging at his wife, her anguished scream, the whimpering cries of their son. And then there is silence, and it is over, and the three faces instantly return to their impassive porcelain state. Their eyes slowly close.  They do not move. So that when they do move again, it is startling.  In abrupt unison, the EYES flash open.  Three pairs of eyes stare straight at us, accusing. Three mouths open, but speak, in rasping tones, as one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The faces linger a moment, the weary eyes slowly close, and the dark reaches forth, and takes them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mocking man) "Johnny, please.  Johnny please."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're scaring me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . DADDY MALE RIGHT (considering) I don't like you any more, Carol.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (imploring) Put the scissors down.  You're scaring me . Please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Carol.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't grab at me!  Let
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Daddy!  No!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Murderer!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SUBURBIA  DAY Morning in America.  Just look at it.  America in the midfifties, the suburban landscape stretching endlessly into the sun drenched distance.  White house upon white house. Emerald lawns, glistening with dew. In each driveway, a big Chevy, or a Ford, muscled with chrome, long tailfins that taper like the fins on rocket ships. Kids burst out of the houses, and zoom down sidewalks on trikes.  Mothers in bright dresses stand in doorways, watching.  The smiling mothers wave to one another, then go back into their houses. Dogs bark, birds sing in trees of just the right height, boys and girls laugh and ring the bells on their trikes.  It is a delicious world, where dogs and birds and children are safe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A family room with all the trappings of the era: a flagstone fireplace, a console TV, a man's leatherette Barca-Lounger, a pipe stand holding two pipes on a nearby table, boxes of children's games neatly stacked on a wall shelf. -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . A young mother, CAROL, her hair -in a pony-tail, stands at a picture window in a corner of the family room, staring mildly at the scene outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A little girl bounces a red ball on the sidewalk.  The ball gets away from her, and rolls into the street. At the same moment, a two-toned CHEVY, lush and huge, rounds the corner. The girl sees the car coming, but still goes after the ball.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carol sees what is about to happen -- but she doesn't cry out, or bang on the window, or run for the front door.  She watches.  And smiles a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The girl careens gleefully into the middle of the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The driver -- a man in a loose fitting dark green suit, white shirt, thin brown tie -- sits behind the steering wheel of the car. Disturbingly, the man's hands are not on the steering wheel. Not only that, he is holding the morning newspaper up in front of him, reading, oblivious to the scene before him. Through the windshield, we see the little girl in the road in front of him, going for her ball.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watches, her smile in place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The little girl picks up her red ball, as the Chevy bears down on her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An alarm suddenly CHIRPS.  The car automatically brakes to a halt.  The man looks around the edge of his paper to see what is happening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The car has stopped, inches from the girl. The girl giggles as, the man in the car gives her a big wink. She waves, then runs back to the sidewalk with her red ball. -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The man goes back to his newspaper, and the car, entirely on its own, starts up again.  The car rounds a corner, and disappears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carol turns away from the window.  She startles when she sees her husband, JOHNNY, is there behind her.  He is in his pajamas.  How long has he been there, watching her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes a step toward her.  He stands there, his thick black hair tousled with sleep, scratching his stubbled jaw, considering her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes another step toward her.  She doesn't move a muscle. A little BOY suddenly enters the room.  Johnny turns, looks at his son, looks back over his shoulder at his wife.  Then, without a word, he begins to walk out of the room.  On his way out, Johnny's eyes flick to Carol's sewing basket, which sits beside a sewing machine.  It is not the sewing that has caught his attention, but a large pair of garment SCISSORS which lie across a fold of colored cloth.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (gruff) Why'd you let me sleep so long?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's Saturday, Johnny, you always -- (beat) Why are you staring at me like that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm unhappy that you let me sleep so long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE HOUSE -- MOMENTS LATER Johnny stands on the front porch, scratching.  He walks down his front walk, and bends over to pick up the newspaper. Carol stands in the doorway, watching him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: slides over Johnny, cast from above.  The air fills with the piercing WHINE of an engine.  Johnny looks up, alarmed. In the sky above him, just beyond the tips of the suburban trees, is a black PRECRIME POLICE HOVERCRAFT. The children, the mothers, Carol in the doorway -- everyone freezes in place, as Johnny is cast into an inexplicable drama. Racing SOUNDLESSLY down the street toward him, are SLEEK TECHNOLOGICAL MARVELS, lethal and efficient looking -- they seem to be cars -- but they are so different from the fat Fords and Chevies in the driveways that it is hard for us to process them. -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Helmeted police with mirrored visors erupt out of the cars. More police drop from the hovercraft in harnesses.  Their uniforms are black, seem actually to absorb light.  Their left hands are bare, their right hands are encased in some sort of complicated glove.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON - A GLOVE The glove is a weapon of some kind, the elongated index finger ending in an open barrel. Clearly, this is not, as it first seemed, the past -- not America in the 1950's.  It is the neo-past, the retro world of America 2040, where the familiar of yesterday is intermeshed with hypertechnology. And all of that hypertechnology is focused on JOHNNY, as he makes a run for the house, sheets of newspaper scattering behind him.  He bursts up the front porch, shoving Carol out of the way. Eight Precrime police officers assemble in the yard. From a backpack, one of them quickly removes an instrument with a handle grip and an ovoid screen.  It is a holographic scanner. He activates it, scans the OFFICER in front of him, and an
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: takes three-dimensional form. The two real officers circle the house, repeating the maneuver a dozen times. In less than a minute, a decoy force of men -- three dimensional, standing in place, but shifting and turning like living beings -- has been created.  An overwhelming police deterrent presence has been established.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Precrime police overwhelm the interior of the house, too.  It is impossible to tell which officers are real, and which are scanned holographs.  The juxtaposition of the futuristic cops in a 1950's style house is disorienting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: T Johnny, in his pajamas, crouches beneath a rack full of his wife's dresses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two OFFICERS, standing back-to-back, hold their gloved hands out in front of them, palm out.  When the first officer points his palm toward a door at the end of the hallway, his glove
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The officer looks at his PALM.  A red thermal IMAGE appears on a small flexible screen -- the heat outline of a crouching man.  The first officer flicks his helmeted head to the second officer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The room is packed with police -- how many are real?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: T Johnny squirms, his pajamas saturated with sweat.  He calls out through the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't do anything!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: T Every OFFICER in the room lifts his gloved hand and points his index barrel at the closet door.  The effect is deeply accusatory. An OFFICER speaks, his VOICE electronically manipulated to be as menacing as possible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing happens.  Two officers aim their barrels at the perimeter of the door.  In repeated, small SONIC BLASTS, the closet door is blown off of its frame, revealing Johnny among the dresses. Johnny starts to rise, and BAM, a section of floorboards is blasted away beneath his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Johnny trips among the splintered floorboards, and drops. He stays on his hands and knees, and approaches.  He lifts his head and looks up at the officer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another OFFICER 2 bends down with a DEVICE -- the words "IdentiScan" on its side -- and blips a red laser light into each of Johnny's, eyes, reading his irises.  The officer nods affirmatively to the other officer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Johnny, on his hands and knees, goes limp.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come out of the closet on your hands and knees.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hands and knees!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Johnny) John Palmer, if you were being arrested for any other crime, I would now read you your rights. (beat) But you are under arrest for the future murderer of your wife, Carol Palmer.  You have no rights.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE HOUSE -- LATER In the background, Johnny is guided into a Precrime police vehicle as the neighbors look on.  Carol and her son stand in the doorway, stunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: remove their helmets.  The first man is tall, sandy-haired, good eyes, deeply blue; This is PAUL ANDERSON, late thirties, Director of the Precrime Division, Washington D.C. The second man is ED WITWER, Anderson's second in command, late thirties, big like Anderson, good face, strong in the shoulders, short brown hair. The two men are deeply comfortable together.  They can speak, or not.  It doesn't matter -- they still communicate.  Two good cops, good together. They walk side-by-side around the house, dematerializing the holographic decoy cops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson seems tired, takes a moment to answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Witwer dematerializes the last decoy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They get to the front of the house and watch the Precrime vehicle holding Johnny zoom SOUNDLESSLY away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thought we might a had a runner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, a runner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A little chase -- that'd been good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fifty cops on the scene takes the chase out of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiles) But only eight of us were real.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'd chase.  You'd love it,.  Man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I love it more Johnny boy doesn't get to murder his wife.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat) It's a beautiful world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SAME SCENE -- LATER The children play on their trikes.  The wives talk among themselves.  The birds sing, the dogs bark. The little girl bounces her red ball again.  She stops a. minute, when two pieces of newspaper blow past her, unexpectantly littering the orderly suburban landscape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Decorated in a 1950's style.  Anderson lies in bed beside his wife, LISA, a pretty, green-eyed brunette.  It is early morning, they are both awake.  Her hand caresses his chest. Maybe they will make love. Lisa's hand stops suddenly on the center of Anderson's chest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns to her, and the grim set of his jaw makes her smile vanish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lisa takes a long breath.  She's been down this road before. She speaks reassuringly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus, Paul.  Your heart's hammering. (playfully) I excite you that much?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I used to love being a cop. LISA You're still a cop.  I'm a factory worker.  We don't catch murderers. We process them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're the best homicide cop in the country.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: snorts disdainfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lisa hugs him, kisses the back of his neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson is silent for a time.  He sighs, then smiles, and turns to his wife, takes her in his arms.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . (beat) You're the Director of a perfect system.  A Cop with a perfect record
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Precogs have a perfect record. They identify the accused -- I just put on my monkey suit and go round them up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And then I prosecute them.  And they go to jail.  And lives are saved. Thousands of lives. (beat) And that's a cop's dream.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.  You're a cop's dream.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE BATHROOM -- LATER Anderson steps out of the shower, and begins to towel himself dry- He glances out a casement window.  He tilts his head, curious, then wipes at the steam on the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LISA Lisa stands in the backyard in her nightgown, talking on a cell phone.  She hangs up, moves quickly back into the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cocks his head, then goes back to toweling off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . KITCHEN -- LATER Checkered linoleum floor.  Appliances out of the 1950's. Except there are little differences.  When Lisa puts a skillet of eggs on the stove, the heating element is not an electric coil, or gas but a shimmering field of light. Lisa is dressed in a blue jersey skirt and a brief jacket. Anderson wears a gray suit, thin blue tie, white shirt, wingtipped shoes.  He doesn't look up from the newspaper as he speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Lisa keeps her back to him as she flips the eggs.  She touches her long brown hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson looks like he's about to say something else, when suddenly someone RAPS on the back screen door.  Anderson and Lisa both turn and smile.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No one.  I called about my hair. Getting it done this afternoon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on in, neighbor.  Want some coffee?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: white-haired, robust, hesitates before coming in.  A thin METALLIC ARM with a red laser light arches quickly down from above the doorway, shines into each of his
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: scanning the irises.  The arm lifts out of view, the screen door UNLATCHES. Frank enters the kitchen, carrying a basket of tomatoes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson laughs, claps his friend and neighbor on the back, teases him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank gives him an ornery look, then a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson gestures for Frank to sit down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lisa sets the eggs down in front of Anderson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank nods and pushes on the screen door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all laugh, Frank exits, Anderson goes back to his paper.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Brought these for your supper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Frank.  That's so sweet.  Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sweet, nothing.  I gotta get rid of these things.  One plant, and I'm invaded by tomatoes.  When I was a kid ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Before all this genetically engineered crap ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah well, it's true.  It used to be a challenge to grow things.  An art. Now you put one plant in the ground
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: then jump the hell out of the way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nah, thanks.  Can't stay.  You guys are rushing off to work anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You and Ellie come for supper then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll barbecue.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You betcha.  We'll bring some more tomatoes -- a new batch will have grown by then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DRIVEWAY -- LATER Anderson waves to Lisa.  Her big Studebaker drives off down the tree-lined street and away. Anderson approaches his Chevy.  He doesn't take out a key to unlock it.  There is no lock.  He slides in behind the wheel. Doesn't take out a key for the ignition -- there is no ignition. A thin METALLIC ARM arches down from the sun visor, scans Anderson's EYES, identifying him.  A seat harness wraps around him, and the car STARTS. Anderson picks up a folder marked "Precrime" and begins to read through the papers.  The Chevy backs out of the driveway and takes him to work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A vast spread of corporate and government buildings -- the spillover from Washington D.C. across the Potomac River into Virginia. Beyond the white of Washington is "The Sprawl" -- the massive unzoned city that has spread uncontrolled on the outskirts of the Capitol.  It is impenetrable and uninviting, especially to those comfortable in the utopian suburbs. Anderson's Chevy moves in a sea of fifties-type cars. Occasionally, an ultramodern vehicle zips past them.  In the sky above is another sea -- of advertising dirigibles, holographic billboards, hovercrafts, skim-jet transports. On one of the holographic billboards giant words begin to flash: "I LIKE MIKE!" -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Then a picture of the smiling President appears.  Then the words: "RE-ELECT PRESIDENT MIKE BILLINGS FOR ANOTHER FOUR YEARS!  KEEP THE PAST IN OUR FUTURE!"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Through his windshield, Anderson glances at a holographic road sign.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: reads: "FBI Headquarters 1 mile.  CIA Headquarters 1.5 miles.  PRECRIME Headquarters 2 miles." Anderson goes back to his papers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson sits in a too large office in a too large chair. He abruptly rises and begins to pace.  The room is large, but he paces like a lion confined in a cage. He punches an intercom.  A female VOICE responds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ed Witwer opens the door to the office., and casually walks in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ed shakes his head, smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson turns away and stares out a large window.  Witwer joins him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Anderson takes a long breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They turn as Ennis PAGE, 44, a thin, tight little man with burr cut hair, knocks and enters the room.  He carries a black BRIEFCASE marked: "Zone 218 - Washington/Alexandria, VA." The case is cuffed to his wrist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Page hesitates, doesn't do it.  Anderson moves quickly to Page.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson leans over the BRIEFCASE.  A small panel recedes, a red laser scanner clicks on, scans Anderson's eyes, BEEPS affirmatively, then clicks off.  The cuff on Page's wrist falls open. Now Page puts the case on Anderson's desk.  Page hesitates. Anderson and Witwer know just what he's going to do.  Page reaches down, unable to resist straightening a pile of papers strewn on Anderson's desk. Anderson and Witwer exchange knowing smiles.  When Page looks up they try to cover, but are not quick enough.  He frowns tightly, and heads for the door. Anderson calls after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Witwer grins to himself as he walks out of the office. Anderson takes a deep breath and goes to his desk, and opens the briefcase.  Four small bright DISCS sit in rows.  He removes one, places it in a VIDEO MONITOR that lifts into view from the center of his desk.  He sits back, weary, and watches. -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Director Anderson?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where's Ennis Page?  Why hasn't he delivered this morning's Precog discs?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll find him, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bullying the staff again, Director Anderson?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Screw you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Was that fun for you, yesterday?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Johnny Palmer bust?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When do we not get our man?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry I'm late, sir.  Precogs put out a heavy national volume this morning -- four for our zone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Put the case on my desk, Ennis.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What was I thinking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks, Ennis. Witwer turns to leave, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now that's a guy who really cares.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A young black woman stands in a hallway.  She stares at a door, gun in hand.  She opens the door, enters a bedroom. She glides toward a bed, where a man lies sleeping.  She lifts the gun and fires it into his sleeping form.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pops the disc, jots down some notes, pops in a new disc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A white woman stands at a stove, cooking.  A man comes up behind her slowly, silently, a necktie taut between his hands. He raises the necktie toward her neck
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's not watching the screen.  He is out of his chair now, looking out the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A tour of Precrime is in progress, like the public relations tours run by present-day FBI.  The TOUR GUIDE, a pretty, smartly uniformed woman in her twenties, leads a group of adults and children, all with glowing nametags, through the building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The group follows the guide slowly through the lobby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She points cheerfully to a stubby little man, MR. HARRIS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An eager boy, TIMMY has the answer to that one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The guide tousles his hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The guide laughs tolerantly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She waves the group on toward an elevator.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Welcome to the main headquarters of Precrime.  Smaller Precrime branches are scattered throughout the United States.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Precrime was established in 2030, with the harnessing of the remarkable talents of the Precognitive mutants.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Harris, can you tell me how many Precogs there are?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . HARRIS Three.  Uh, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's exactly right!  A lot of people assume there are Precogs in every branch office. (MORE) -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But there are only three Precogs, right here in this building.  And the information they give us, we send out to all the other branches. (beat) And what is that information -what do the Precogs do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They protect us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (chipper voice) That's right, Timmy.  Because of the Precogs, you're going to grow up murderfree.  Isn't that something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . HARRIS They ever wrong?  The Precogs ever screw up when they predict a murder?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never, sir.  It's an infallible system.  The Precogs predict a homicide, and our Precrime police then apprehend that future murderer before the event occurs.  And right next door is the Judicial Center, where we prosecute the future murderers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can we see the Precogs?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I'm sorry.  That part of the building is not open to the public. (beat) Now, if you'll just step this way ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The chamber is an elaborate, hypertech hospital, constructed for the maintenance of three beings -- the Precogs.  They are triplets -- two of the Precogs are male, one is female. -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Technicians swarm all over them like worker bees.  The bodies of the Precogs are being tended to: exercised, cleansed, groomed. The head of each Precog is encased in a complex, ornate HELMET that seems to be an amalgam of organic tissues and bright metallics.  The helmets pulse slightly, and the surfaces seem to flow and shift, like oil on water. A network of micro-thin cables that are actually strands of light, rise Medusa-like from each helmet, then centralize into a single strand, and connect to a massive mainframe computer. The Precogs appear to be in suspended animation, or in comas. They are absolutely still and limp -- except for their faces. Their faces are in constant motion, the lips mouthing scenes from murders only they can see.  Life for a Precog is an endless cycle of death.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON - THE FEMALE PRECOG we recognize her fragile and perfect FACE from the opening scene of the movie.  She floats in a glowing nutritive bath. Like her brothers, she seems to be eternally young, or eternally old. The technicians lift her from her bath.  She is dried, dressed in a robe, then guided into an over-sized, throne like chair. Her brothers are guided into their thrones, on either side of her. Not once are their helmets removed.  What they feed into the mainframe is too valuable.  It must be gathered twenty-four unrelenting hours a day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ennis Page sits in a room just off the Precog Chamber.  He can see them through a large window.  He works a large computer console, the gathering point for the information the Precogs constantly feed the computer. Perhaps every ten seconds, a small DISC is released by the computer, and mechanically gathered, sorted, and placed -under Page's watchful eye -- into a black case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson grips the wheel of his Chevy, driving down 1-95. The fact that he can't control his car -- that the steering wheel has no function, his speed is predetermined, and his direction is guided by satellite -- is maddening now. From inside the cars that glide along beside him people turn and look curiously at the man who is actually gripping his steering wheel. Anderson slams it with his fist.  Through his windshield Anderson sees a four year old boy in the driver's seat of a passing red and black Ford.  His mother sits in the passenger's seat, blithely reading.  The boy mimics Anderson, gleefully slams his steering wheel too, then laughs. Anderson turns and looks the other way, into the distance, at the "Sprawl,' the vast unzoned city attached to Washington D.C. You can see it in his face: a man could lose himself in there.

direction.raw_text: . THE SPRAWL  NIGHT The unzoned city is full of 1950's iconography, but it all feels different than it did in the suburbs.  Where the burbs were Ike, the city is Joseph McCarthy. The fat Ramblers and Studebakers have a little grime on them. The women's dresses are tighter and more urgent, the men's suits have some shine at the elbows.  You look over your shoulder here, move faster, and smile a lot less. And some streets you don't go on at all.  Anderson's Python moves down one of them.  He stops under a blackened suspension bridge, gets out.  He's still in uniform.  He holds a duffel bag. He starts to walk away from the Python, then hesitates. He's left the door open.  He shakes his head at his sloppiness.  Goes back and shuts the door.  Walks away again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's left a small DEVICE on the passenger's seat.  Digital numbers shoot by in reverse.  Something CLICKS.

direction.raw_text: Anderson continues walking away.  He doesn't look back as the Python is engulfed in a miniature sun of heat and flame. direction.raw_text: Precrime officers pour down the stairs toward the train platform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Witwer watches on the MAP at all the little symbols merging together, like a gameboard -- but this game ends in a reallife confrontation between one man and an army of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks urgently to the phone technician
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Witwer presses his ear to the phone.  He can hear the subway make its STOP.  Then he hears a chorus of mechanized VOICES -the voices of the Precrime police, the SCREAMS of panicked passengers
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You wouldn't shoot a cop would you, Paul? (beat) Paul?  Paul?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's still on the line.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Police.  Everyone down on your hands and knees! (then) Oh, shit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Precrime officers aim the index barrels of their gloveweapons at ANDERSON, who sits blithely on a seat, holding his cell phone to his ear. Anderson begins to shimmer, then dematerialize ghost-like, into nothingness.  He was a holographic decoy. What is actually there on the train seat is Anderson's cell phone.  Rigged to its mouthpiece is a tiny digital voice recorder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson trots up the stairs and safely out onto the streets of The Sprawl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Every city has its underbelly.  If you lifted the fat dark underbelly of The Sprawl this is where you'd end up. The streets here feel like alleys, clotted and tight.  There are streetlights, bright ones -- but the light dies at its source, never makes it through the sour air down to the ground. The retro fifties look comes apart here.  The people that you see -- and you only catch quick glimpses of them, they move like rats -- wear black mostly, tight fitting tech-fibers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: caught one of the rats, a thin bald guy in black. Anderson has him pinned up against a wall.  They're having some kind of exchange -- which consists of the guy answering none of Anderson's questions, and Anderson pressing him harder against the wall. Finally, the guy does something odd.  He lifts a finger and pulls down Anderson's right lower eyelid.  Anderson lets him.  Then the guy does the same on the left.  Has a long look.  And then nods.  Anderson releases him, and they go off together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . AN APARTMENT BUILDING -- LATER An oppressive brick thing on a side street.  The facade is crumbling.  Nothing good happens in a building like this.. The guy leads Anderson to the building, then scurries off into the night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ROOM -- LATER A stained overstuffed chair in the corner, a dreary little kitchen with crusted dishes in the sink. But jarringly, in the center of all this, is a make-shift hypertech medical setup: a gleaming operating table, an array of lasers, scalpels and surgical equipment, an anesthesia console. Anderson sits in a chair facing DOC.  DOC is a big man with delicate fingers.  He sneezes, then blows his nose hard into a handkerchief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson looks at him uneasily.  It's not just DOC -- it's the whole setup, the needles and scalpels, the medical thing, which Anderson truly does not care for.  Doc sneezes again, then looks up at his patient. -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doc chuckles.  Then he waits, expectantly. Anderson hands him a tiny opalescent card.  A preset cash card.  DOC slides it into small console, watches the numbers flash up.  He frowns, sighs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He waits.  Doc's not thrilled, but finally, he nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Time to got down to business.  Doc walks over to a large medical cabinet and opens the door.  It's full of EYES, and parts of eyes -- 611 !  A cryo-jars. Anderson tightens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson knows this, too, wishes Doc would shut up ANDERSON Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson rises up out of his chair and goes over to the operating table.  He lies down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Anderson lies there, blinking up at the ceiling.  He listens to Doc preparing instrument trays.  It's a bad sound.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Got a cold.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry.  I could cut open your chest, sew a dead cat in there, and you'd never get an infection.  Not with the spectrum antibios I'll be shooting into you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not here for cat surgery, Doc.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's all I could safely move
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.  All right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You understand what I told you then. I can't just give you new irises. The Scanners will read the scar tissue.  Alarms will go off.

dialogue.raw_text: I'm a cop, I know
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I gotta take your eyes out.

dialogue.raw_text: And put in new ones.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.  I get it, DOC.

direction.raw_text: . THE SPRAWL -- DAY The suspension bridge where we saw Anderson vaporize the Python transport.  Witwer stands watching as a Precrime techno-unit sifts through the white ashes. Witwer lifts his face to the acrid breeze coursing off the Potomac.  It's a pose a track dog might hold, nose up, testing the air for a scent.

direction.raw_text: We can't see anything at first, because Anderson can't see anything either.  He's in a deep post-surgical haze.  DOC'S voice comes to him.  It's warped and ugly.

direction.raw_text: Anderson makes an affirmative grunt. Now we see his surroundings, even though Anderson still can't.  He lies in a grungy bed, his head and eyes swathed in white dressings. Doc stands over him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson grunts weakly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doc takes an air-syringe out of his pocket and touches it to Anderson's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doc presses the tip into the soft underpart of Anderson's chin.  Anderson jumps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Finally, Doc takes a small clock out of his pocket and places it on a dresser beside Anderson's bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson, groggy, starts to say something else, but then he hears a door open and close, and Doc is gone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Don't take the bandages off for twenty four hours.  You'll go blind if you do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're in a room.  I had you moved here, a couple miles from my place. If they find you, they don't find me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A guy will come in, feed you once. (beat) I juiced up the nano-reconstruction around your new eyes, 'cause I know you're in a hurry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Fuzzily)) Nano-re ...construction.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Organic microrobots that reconstruct nerves and blood vessels.  It'll feel like fleas chewing on your eyeballs.  Don't scratch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm giving you a bonus, might come in handy.  Feel this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a temporary paralytic enzyme. Someone spots you, you duck into an alley, shoot this under your chin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The enzyme turns your facial muscles to mush.  You won't look like the same man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You tighten up again in about thirty minutes.  Hurts like nothing you ever felt.  It's vicious, but effective.  I'll put it in your bag.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm setting up a timer.  When it buzzes tomorrow, take off your bandages, and get the hell out of here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE SPRAWL -- NIGHT The Precrime presence mounts on the streets.  A couple of units move past the boarding house, but they don't stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BOARDING HOUSE ROOM -- DAY Anderson sits in a chair, his dressings like a blindfold. He looks like a hostage.  He is sweating.  Keeps reaching for his dressings to scratch, then forces himself not to. He speaks to someone we don't yet see.  The guy DOC said would come.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now the camera moves and we see who it is that has been sent to help Anderson.  It's the rat guy, the thin bald man Anderson had roughed up the day before.  The guy has a bowl of hot soup in his hands.  He stares contemptuously at Anderson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The rat guy doesn't say a word.  He simply tips the hot soup and it splatters down into Anderson's lap.  Anderson cries out in pain and surprise.  The guy walks out of the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Guess I should eat. (Beat) You gonna help feed me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So how do we do this, pal?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ON- THE TIMER Twenty hours gone by.  Four more to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Precrime cops are shaking down any of the rats they can catch, looking for leads, looking for anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The TIMER shows one hour to go.  Anderson sits in a chair, squirming miserably.  His dressings are wet with sweat, and frayed and dirty at the edges where he has tugged and plucked at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is this close to ripping the dressings off
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to himself) Fuck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Precrime transport stops.  Two officers get out.  One of them sets up a large thermal scanner on the sidewalk, and does a read on the boarding house.  The other does a read on a pawn shop and bar next door.. The OFFICER 1 doing Anderson's boarding house, calls to the other officer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The Officer 1 opens the back of the transport, and takes out a box.  He removes four round BALLS.  They are silver, as big as billiard balls. He goes up to the boarding house, gets IdentiScanned, and the front door opens.  He rolls the balls down a dark hallway. Then he goes back out to the transport, and leans against it, bored.  He holds up an electronic clipboard and waits for the data to come in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Got 27 warm bodies in this place. What should it take, three or four Spiders?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The BALLS roll about eight feet, then suddenly come to autolife as they spin.  They open like flowers -- flowers with legs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON : A BALL A fist-sized Spider takes shape.  On its head is an IdentiScan lens mounted on a thin metallic antenna.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An OLD WOMAN sits at a card table eating a bowl of something unidentifiable.  She looks up with annoyance as she sees a spider scuttling across the floor toward her.  It makes a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: sound on the floor as it comes.  She's poor, living in The Sprawl -- she knows the drill.  She continues to eat as the SPIDER crawls up the leg of the card table.  She barely watches as it moves past her bowl and toward her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles toothlessly at her joke The Spider hops onto her am and inches up, then moves across her shoulder.  It grips her cheek lightly, as the IdentiScan antenna reads her eyes. Then it leaps off her and onto the floor and CLICKS away across the linoleum.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's nice to have a little company
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Precrime officer lifts his clipboard and checks a column with his laser pen, and waits for the next one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson sits in his chair.  He cocks his head, listening. His body tenses.  Something feels wrong. The TIMER shows ten minutes to go.  Blindfolded for a day and a night, Anderson has no idea how much time he has left. Three seconds, four hours? A flattened SPIDER squeezes under his door.  Anderson tenses as it CLICKS across the floor toward him. -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He knows that sound. Anderson stumbles up and out of his chair.  He starts to grab at his dressings, remembers Doc's warning, and stops himself.  The SPIDER waits for him to settle, then CLICKS toward him again. Anderson moves around the room, avoiding the Spider.  He is dripping with sweat, starting to breathe hard.  The Spider comes faster.  Anderson crashes into a table, brings it down. Falls across the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Officer 1 squints at his clipboard.  One of the Spiders is taking too long.  He adjusts his thermal scanner, and sees the heat outline of a man bouncing around a room. The other Officer 2 finishes reading the pawn shop and the barroom, then wanders over to Officer 1. They both watch the screen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Stinking drunk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat) Or a guy who doesn't want to get read.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Anderson forces himself to sit still, because he knows the consequences.  The Spider advances, starts up his leg. The TIMER has not buzzed.  Anderson can't touch his dressings. The Spider moves across his shoulder and onto his face.  It
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and HUMS trying to adjust its antenna against the dressings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The officers eye the thermal scanner, as they reach for their mirrored helmets, getting ready to go in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Spider crawls all over Anderson's head, trying to get past the dressings for a read. Anderson has no choice.  None.  He starts to lift at his dressing.  The Spider senses his cooperation, freezes in place. Anderson wants to scream.  He unwraps his head, tugs the eye pads away from his eyes.  He rips them off.  The Spider sits on his shoulder, waiting. -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Anderson's eyes are tightly closed.  He opens them
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Light brighter than a magnesium burn, brighter than a nuclear flashpoint.  Light to buckle the knees and push the brain beyond endurance. And though all this the faraway sound of a BUZZER going off. The TIMER has finally sounded.  Anderson's open eyes are streaming with tears, but he has survived the moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It comes into slow focus The Spider, all business, reads his eyes.  Then, as if nothing unusual has occurred, it jumps off his shoulder, and crosses the floor.  It flattens, scoots under the door, and is gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The officers see that the Spider has gotten its read.  They pull off their helmets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They start putting their equipment back into the transport.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let's eat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Anderson stares at himself in a dusty mirror.  His new eyes are tender and bloodshot.  And they are not blue, like the ones he was born with, but a deep brown.  Anderson is exactly the same, and utterly different. He grabs his duffel bag, and gets the hell out of there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PRECRIME HEADQUARTER'S -- DAY Lisa, looking drawn and scared, sits in Witwer's office. Witwer isn't looking too well, either.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lisa nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Witwer's eyes imp involuntarily to a CLOCK on his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The words are leading them no place good.  They stop talking, and just sit there.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They told me to move into Paul's office.  I said fuck you very much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) I don't want to do any of this, Lisa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat) Everybody's got their reasons for wanting you in charge.  So do I -- you won't bring him in dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.  But if he shoots a cop ... (beat) Which is what he does four days from now, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He'd never hurt you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know that.  But the other thing I know is -- the Precogs are never wrong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Anderson stands on a street corner waiting in line with several people waiting for the N0.6 Turbo Tram. The double decker Tram comes.  People get off, then the line starts to move forward as people get on. Anderson fidgets.  He's last in line.  Each person gets IdentiScanned as he boards.  Anderson's putting his new eyes to the test.  If the scan goes wrong, he's positioned himself to run. The woman ahead of him, gets scanned, pays her fare. Anderson's turn.  Anderson goes up the steps, and a red beam reads his eyes. The Tram DRIVER glances at a monitor beside his steering wheel, then nods at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson nods, moves casually to the back.  But his jaw muscles are flexing hard, working off the tension.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Welcome aboard, Mr. Symington.  Plenty of seats in the back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . A WEALTHY HOME - SUBBURIAN WASHINGTON -- NIGHT Senator Malcolm releases a self satisfied little belch as he finishes off a late night whiskey in his panelled den.  He wanders about admiring himself in the many political photos adorning the cherry wood walls. -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He's feeling cozy and safe, the way rich people can afford to.  No IdentiScan Spiders would ever be sent under his doors. No intrusions of any sort, nothing that a coiffed secretary or a loyal wife wouldn't announce before hand. Which is why he doesn't immediately understand the small
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: at ear level, coming from just behind him.  It's a metallic CLICK-CLICK.  He turns amiably.  His eyes instantly widen, and his knees buckle when he sees he's looking into the barrel of ANDERSON'S cocked gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Senator Malcolm tries to regain his composure.  His fear embarrasses him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Senator finds his voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson presses the gun to the Senator's forehead.  He slides the barrel tip back and forth across the Senator's sweaty skin.  It makes a greasy red mark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can almost see a thought dawning on Senator Malcolm. And then, shockingly he spits in Anderson's face, and turns and walks to the other side of the den.  His tone is mocking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson realizes this, too, lowers his gun.  The Senator is even laughing now.  For a moment Anderson does nothing, then he moves toward the Senator again. -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The Senator stands his ground smugly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Senator is laughing hard now.  Anderson lets him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson hits the Senator so hard it bounces him across the floor and into the cherry wood panelling.  Several of his beloved photos crash down onto him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson steps over him, and walks out of the room
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Time to upgrade your alarm system, Senator.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your work-up of Witwer.  The Security Panel would've done one. (beat) Why do I kill Witwer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's no motive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's, always a motive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I could've come to anyone on the panel.  But I picked you. (beat) Of all the shits on that panel, I like you least of all.  So if this gun goes off, I'll feel bad, but not, you know, devastated.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the fuck was I worried about? You can't kill me.  The Precogs would've seen it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Witwer's clean.  You're clean. There's nothing.  No motive.  Kind of like something Kafka would've cooked up. (beat) You like that, cockroach?  You're fucked and you'll never know why.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell you something about the Precogs, Senator.  They're great on murder. But it's the little things they fail to see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Little things like that, for instance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . PRECRIME HEADQUARTERS -- DAY Search and Command room.  Witwer stands there amidst all of the technology speaking to a group of Precrime officers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No one says anything, and then LIEUTENANT GLASER, 30, speaks up.

direction.raw_text: The officers look at their shoes.

direction.raw_text: . Lieutenant Glaser tries again.

direction.raw_text: Witwer's eyes flick to a digital CLOCK on the wall.  It's something he can't help doing now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Witwers admiring smile makes his men very uncomfortable .
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He hasn't shown up on one goddamn IdentiScan in three days.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's found a room -- he's going to sit it out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, except for holding a gun to senator Malcolm's goddman head in his own goddman house last night, Anderson's sitting it out! (beat) Why hasn't he been scanned?

dialogue.raw_text: Hes beating the scanners
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No one beats the scanners.

dialogue.raw_text: He's done his eyes
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But the scarring always
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He went the whole way. The crazy bastard had his eyes removed.  New ones sewn in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That takes weeks to heal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you're prepared to go blind, a street surgeon'll juice up the repair cycle.  They don't give a fuck about risk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's going to do what it takes to stay free -- if it blinds him, maims him, or kills him.

direction.raw_text: A mother places a carton of milk on a table in front of her teenage son.  He pours it into his cereal bowl, then puts the carton down in front of him. There's a flexible Vid-Screen on the side of the carton, about the size of a playing card.  AS the sleepy kid watches, the disposable Vid-Screen sparkles to life. Nothing unusual, they always do that.  For advertisements, lost kids, or in this case crime bulletins. A good one.  The kid straightens up. -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A fully rotating mug shot of PAUL ANDERSON fills the screen, followed by vital statistics and details of the precrime he's been charged with. The kid watches for a while, then gets bored, and pulls the Dexi-Pops cereal box over and starts reading the back of that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A big man in a tee shirt lies on a couch, a bowl of popcorn perched on his belly.  He stares at a TV monitor that's the size of a twin bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson's face fills the monitor.  The TV image is so big that Anderson overwhelms the room with his video presence. It's like God coming to pay a visit -- even if you want to avoid Him you can't. The big man with the popcorn tries to do just that.  He surfs through a zillion channels, but Anderson's visage is omnipresent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson's face fills the skies, too.  Witwer and Precrime have pulled out all the stops. Advertising dirigibles float by with Anderson's image on it. Holographic billboards with Anderson hover in the air.  There are so many Andersons in the sky he seems to be part of the weather, a special type of cloud. People on the streets look up, briefly interested, then go about their business.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One person who is paying deep attention to all this is Anderson himself.  He stands on a street corner, wearing dark glasses and a fedora, staring at a public video kiosk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The mug shot of Anderson disappears and is replaced by a Precrime SPOKESWOMAN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stares at the kiosk as people on the street begin to gather around excitedly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The United States Supreme Court has issued a special injunction allowing the unprecedented public viewing of former Precrime Director Paul Anderson's future murder of Edward Witwer, the current Director. -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His mouth slowly opens.  He steps back against a wall and slides his hand into his pants pocket.  He looks at the Precog DISC in his cupped hand, then quickly puts it away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: look into the sky, in store windows, at other video kiosks.  They have the enthralled anticipation of a mob at a public guillotining.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The OLD GUY him nudges him
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And there it is, Anderson and Witwer standing there pointing guns at each other.  The whole thing just as we saw it before. All the way through to the fatal moment.

direction.raw_text: Anderson shoots him.  Witwer slumps, dying.  The video stops. And then begins to play all over again, right from the start, the 1-800-PRECRIME number scrolling along the bottom of it. "Call now!  Call now!  Call now!
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: She continues her declamation
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The video you are about to see, generated by the Precognitive mutants, is the immutable evidence of the infallible system. (reassuring smile) Citizens are urged to call
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: with any information that may lead us to the whereabouts of Paul Anderson, future murderer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shakes his head in confusion and disbelief.  But he has the Precog disc ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This oughtta be good, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Ed ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ennis Page sits on a bar stool at the far end of a bar so full of cigarette smoke it doesn't seem capable of supporting life.  But it supports the kind of life Page is interested in. An emaciated woman with a feral smile slides onto a stool beside Page.  He gives one shake of his head, and she slides away again.  His eyes cut to a group of females.  He waits for the next approach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON: PAGE as a HAND reaches over his shoulder and places a Precog disc on the bar in front of him.  Page makes a sound and tries to jump away, as if the disc is something lethal.  Which it is, in a way. Anderson presses him back down on his stool.  Sits next to him.  Page stares at him, scared.  Anderson looks straight ahead as he speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can almost see Page's heart slamming in his chest.  He tries to hide it with tough talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Page looks unhappily at the disc on the bar PAGE You got a disc Anderson picks it up, holds it tight in his fist
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson waits.  Lets Page work through it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson is barely breathing, he's listening so hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson looks around.  Patrons are beginning to look over in his direction, eyes lingering.  He rises. Page seems in a daze.
